description: From Middle English ganet, gante, from Old English ganot, from Proto-West Germanic *ganat, *ganatō, from Proto-Germanic *ganataz, *ganutô (“gander”), ultimately related to Proto-Germanic *ganzô.

entries.meaning: Any of three species of large seabird in the genus Morus, of the family Sulidae. They have black and white bodies and long pointed wings, and hunt for fish by plunge diving and pursuing their prey underwater.
(chiefly Britain, South Africa) A voracious eater; a glutton.

verbs.description: gannet (third-person singular simple present gannets, present participle ganneting, simple past and past participle ganneted)

entries.meaning: (chiefly transitive, informal, Britain) To wolf down, gobble or eat (something) voraciously.
examples: She was no longer in the company of her older sister and mother who had often scolded her for ganneting down her food.
